title: Asthma Impairment and Risk Questionnaire (AIRQ)
description: Validates asthma control in patients 12 years and older by assessing both symptom impairment and exacerbation risk domains

parameters.name: daytime_symptoms
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness bothered you during the day on more than 4 days?

parameters.name: nighttime_awakenings
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness woke you up from sleep more than 1 time?

parameters.name: activity_limitation
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness limited the activities you want to do every day?

parameters.name: rescue_medication_daily
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness caused you to use your rescue inhaler or nebulizer every day?

parameters.name: social_activity_limitation
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, did you have to limit your social activities (such as visiting with friends/relatives or playing with pets/children) because of your asthma?

parameters.name: exercise_limitation
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, did coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness limit your ability to exercise?

parameters.name: difficult_control
parameters.description: In the past 2 weeks, did you feel that it was difficult to control your asthma?

parameters.name: oral_steroids
parameters.description: In the past 12 months, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness caused you to take steroid pills or shots, such as prednisone or methylprednisolone?

parameters.name: emergency_visits
parameters.description: In the past 12 months, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness caused you to go to the emergency room or have unplanned visits to a health care provider?

parameters.name: hospitalization
parameters.description: In the past 12 months, has coughing, wheezing, shortness of breath, or chest tightness caused you to stay in the hospital overnight?

result.name: airq_score
result.description: Total AIRQ score based on number of 'yes' responses (0-10 points)

ranges.interpretation: Asthma is well-controlled. Continue current management and monitor regularly. Even well-controlled patients can have asthma attacks, but the risk is lower.
Asthma control is suboptimal. Consider step-up therapy, review inhaler technique and adherence. Increased risk of exacerbations compared to well-controlled patients.
Asthma is very poorly controlled with significant impairment and high exacerbation risk. Requires immediate therapeutic intervention and specialist referral consideration.

references: Murphy KR, Chipps B, Beuther DA, Wise RA, McCann W, Gilbert I, et al. Development of the Asthma Impairment and Risk Questionnaire (AIRQ): a composite control measure. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2020;8(7):2263-2274.e5.

Beuther DA, Murphy KR, Zeiger RS, Wise RA, McCann W, Reibman J, et al. The Asthma Impairment and Risk Questionnaire (AIRQ) Control Level Predicts Future Risk of Asthma Exacerbations. J Allergy Clin Immunol Pract. 2022;10(12):3204-3212.e2.
formula: Sum of 'yes' responses to all 10 questions. Score range: 0-10 points
notes: The AIRQ is a validated tool for patients aged 12 years and older with physician-diagnosed asthma
The questionnaire includes both impairment (7 items, 2-week recall) and risk (3 items, 12-month recall) domains
Cut-point of ≥2 for separating well-controlled versus all others has sensitivity of 0.90 and specificity of 0.79
Cut-point of ≥5 has specificity of 0.95 for identifying very poorly controlled asthma
Higher scores indicate worse asthma control and increased risk of future exacerbations
The AIRQ should be used as part of comprehensive clinical assessment and shared decision-making
